text: the deponent herein, having first been duly sworn on oath, was examined and testified as follows: EXAMINATION
Good afternoon, Doctor.  We met a few minutes ago. I am taking your deposition today, and I am going to assume that I don't need to give you instructions on testifying at a deposition.  Am I correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If we need to straighten anything out, we'll do it along the way. Your title here is the Chief of the Division of Cardiothoracic Surgery?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you're an M.D., correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you're an employee of duPont/Nemours?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you review any records in preparation for your deposition today?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I just looked at my operative report.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And from what date?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I believe they're in March 2014.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, I have one that I'm going to show you from the 27th.  That's your original --
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Operative report?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- procedure, right.  And then the second one is from the 29th, which was when you were called emergently in.  Okay?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So aside from the records that you reviewed, do you have any recollection of Lily Lynn Trudnak and recollection of events that occurred on March 29th when you were called in emergently?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Some.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Some.  Okay.  All right. What do you recall about it?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: This was a patient with tetralogy of Fallot and some respiratory issues who came from Connecticut Children's Hospital. And I remember receiving a phone call from a physician who used to be a trainee here stating that they had this complex case, that it was, you know, turning to sort of an unmanageable situation for them. And the baby had several cardiac arrests and hypoxic episodes and was paralyzed, and they had a very difficult time providing adequate ventilation. And the patient had tetralogy of Fallot that needed to have repair, and so the expertise, seemingly after a conversation, of that institution was that was not present there and that they were seeking for the opportunity to get care somewhere else.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And she was admitted to duPont specifically for the cardiac surgery, as I recall.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I believe so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  What was her condition like preoperatively as far as her neurologic picture?  Do you recall?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Hard to say considering that this is a patient who is mechanically ventilated, sedated.  It's a newborn, and therefore besides gross motor movements and opening eyes, certainly not -- I wouldn't be able to give you more information than that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Understood. I want you to look at your report of the 27th.  And I will find that for you.  Unfortunately I didn't bring -- I should have brought a separate mouse for you.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Now, you control this, or I do?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I control.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But next time I do this I'm going to bring a mouse for my deponent so they can do that. So this is the beginning of your operative report, and can you see it?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So this is the report you were referring to, the first document that you reviewed.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So the report speaks for itself.  For the record, this is Bates No. 152, and it continues.  It's a report signed by Dr. Christian Pizarro, and it's of a procedure dated 3/27/2014.  The note was submitted or signed or filed, it looks like at the top left, at 4/7/2014.  And it describes an operation that occurred on March 27, 2014. In the category under surgeon and assistant, you're listed as the surgeon.  There's a Dr. Glenn Pelletier listed.  Who is Dr. Pelletier?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: He's another cardiothoracic surgeon who works here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  He's full-time here?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And Edward Woodford I had the pleasure of meeting a week or two ago. He is a physician assistant that works with your department regularly.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And John Ostrowski was the anesthesiologist, correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I believe so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  That's what's listed here.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And you've had the opportunity to review this report.  Was there any particular difficulty -- and I'm putting it in a layperson's term.  I don't pretend to have the expertise that you have in the ins and outs of intricate surgery like this.  But was this a procedure that went pretty much as you expected it to go?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  No particular problems with this surgery per se, correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: No.  I would say that, yeah, things went according to plan.  The patient had, you know, a good anatomic repair, and it seems like cardiac function was good and there were no issues to the point that we closed the chest.  Any time we will have a concern, we'll leave the chest open.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: And so, yeah, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And it's also mentioned in here sort of in the middle of the page I'm showing there that there was assistance of Dr. Baffa.  I understand that Dr. Baffa is an intensivist, cardiology intensivist.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is Dr. Baffa's specialty?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: She's a cardiologist who has special training in imaging, so she's the person who helped with the assessment of my echocardiogram at the end of the procedure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And that was an epicardial echocardiogram, correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Baby's esophagus was too small to pass the scope?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Well, there was a concern about the size of the baby as well as the fact that the airway was questionable, and therefore we didn't want to add any potential encumbering, you know, issue associated with that.  So, you know, a probe is generally not designed for patients of this size, so they tend to be oversized, and that's a problem.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And if I may, what was your understanding of the airway problem that this baby had?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Well, the baby received a tracheostomy at the previous institution because of the difficulties that they had in spite of that.  The patient did have several episodes when it was important, desaturation that led to arrest, and therefore that was part of the issue is the cardiac defect was the respiratory problem, anatomic problem. And therefore when the patient came we evaluated that, you know, anew and we established that obviously the tracheostomy provided a good access to the airway and that the airway in fact were not all that small. And the patient at the time had an annoying, you know, infection with Serratia, which is a Gram-negative organism that makes -- obviously could aggravate matters, and that was, you know, being treated. But we thought that considering the ability to ventilate effectively, the presence of a concurrent infectious inflammatory process in the airway, it certainly would not be, you know, an absolute mandate to try to tackle the cardiac defect and the airway surgery at the same time considering the fact that that combination certainly has far important morbidity, mortality, and risk compared to just the isolated cardiac surgery. So we thought that that was certainly not something that we should try to address at that particular time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood.  And you note that the area, actually the area of her trachea, cross-sectional area had increased over time.  Is that correct?  You said there was, I think in the sixth line from the bottom or seventh line, significant increase in size compared to the previous study from seven weeks before?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Seemingly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.  And you then went to the trouble in your history here of explaining particularly, I think as you stated, why you did not want to do any particular tracheal intervention as far as a tracheal reconstruction at that time, the same time that you were performing the cardiac surgery, but that you would rather reassess that at a later date.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  All right. So moving on, what -- I know the reason, but what is the reason that in this procedure and in other cardiac procedures where patients come to the operating room with a tracheostomy and they need a median sternotomy, what's the reason that the tracheostomy tube is removed at that time?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Well, generally speaking it's severalfold, but importantly you want to, A, have the anesthesiologist get direct access to the airway, which would be in the face, correct?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Correct.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: And therefore easier than, you know, below the chin, particularly in a patient who is about 50 centimeters long. So that goes without saying. The second is the fact that ideally you want to -- you know, there is a risk of contamination and deep-seated mediastinal wound infection every time you have a contaminated source, you know, immediately adjacent to the sternotomy. So ideally you want to see if you could create some form of a barrier to separate those two, and so it's impossible to do with a tracheostomy in place. And therefore generally we will just take the tracheostomy out, if feasible intubate a patient, you know, orally or nasotracheally, you know, from above, and then seal this and then prep the sternum -- I mean the chest where the sternotomy is going to take place.  So --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: To your knowledge was there any difficulty on the part of the anesthesiologist in exchanging the tubes?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I have no recollection.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So then --
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: It wasn't brought up to me, but I have no idea.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Is that something if there was a problem that you would have noted in your -- put in your operative note?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Not in my note, but it would be probably noted by the anesthesiologist, I would imagine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Fair enough. At some point then postoperatively a tracheostomy patient with need for a tracheostomy is going to have a tracheostomy tube reinserted.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have or is there at duPont here -- I'll do this separately.  Is there at duPont any policy, procedure, or protocol for how long after the initial cardiac operation one should wait before reinserting the tracheostomy?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I'm not sure of a written policy. I think that in general as a medical guideline we operate, you know, under the principle that generally if all is well, within, you know, 24 to 48 hours we will reinsert a tracheostomy considering the fact that it's amazing how quickly a tracheostomy orifice will close down. And then once that starts happening and you're trying to dilate and put this foreign body there again, there is possibility of bleeding, et cetera, et cetera, and that's the last thing we want, is blood in the airway, particularly in someone who has these kind of, you know, issues. So I would say the norm is probably 48 hours, you know, give or take.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think you said maybe even as early as 24.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: If everything is well, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, I looked at the date involved here.  The surgery was on 3/27.  That was a Thursday.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The procedure that we're concerned with where you were called in emergently was on the 29th, which was a Saturday.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that a usual thing here at duPont for -- in a patient like this who needs a tracheostomy exchange, to do it on a Saturday?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: It wouldn't be unusual.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you aware that it was going to take place in this case, in Lily Lynn Trudnak's case, that Dr. Barth was going to do it on a Saturday?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I believe so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you said you -- would you have an objection to waiting another couple of days until a Monday if that were necessary?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I wouldn't see a reason to wait.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  But would it cause a problem?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Well, it's hard to -- it's hard to know.  You know, I've seen trachs close in, you know, less than 72 hours or just about where it's been difficult to reinsert, you know, the tube again.  So yeah, we generally don't go there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  All right.  So who determined when the tracheostomy was going to be changed?  Was that your determination, or was that Dr. Barth?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I think it was probably a discussion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I mean, I don't have a specific recollection of that, but generally speaking that's the way it will go. We will talk with the person who -- or the team that would generally be doing that, which would include ENT, anesthesiologist, and, you know, people in the ICU and surgeon and said everything looks good, we should go ahead and do this. That's generally the way this goes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were you aware that it was going to be done that Saturday?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I believe so because -- yeah, I believe so because I believe I was on call that weekend.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So when you're on call, you don't stay in the hospital.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: No.  Unless there's something that requires my attention.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How are you notified if there's an emergency that you have to attend to?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I generally get called.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Telephone?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Telephone, beeper.  Generally, yeah, telephone or beeper, direct call.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: On a weekend -- I understand that there's a full team that needs to be assembled to do a cardiothoracic operation, and you have -- there's a special dedicated cardiothoracic team here including nurses --
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- and physician assistant and perfusionist and so forth. What's the availability of that team, to your knowledge, on the weekend? Are they here at the hospital, or are they on call remotely?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: No.  The vast majority are on call within I would say, you know, 15 minutes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And that was my next question.  Is there sort of a distance or a time limit?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I mean, most folks, if you looked at them, we're incredibly close.  I live eight minutes away.  The perfusionist is probably ten.  The scrub nurse is five.  So yeah, we're pretty close.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you recall where you were when you got the notification you were needed that day?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: No.  Most likely home, but no, I don't recall specifically.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall how long it took you to come in?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Nothing.  I mean, I was here in really -- the time I got the call until -- it would have been certainly less than ten minutes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall who notified you, who called you?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you know what information you were given, anything as to why you were needed?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: My recollection was Baby Trudnak, they were doing the trach change and they had difficulty and --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'll go to that part.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: -- they need you to come in emergently.  That's all.  And then that was it.  I was on my way.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That is -- I have now in front of you your note from that day, the 29th, which is Bates No. 157 --
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- and, for the record, continues to 158.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So we can refer to that if you need to. Did you proceed immediately to OR 1 when you got here?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And who was -- do you recall who was already in the operating room when you got there?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I believe that a scrub nurse of cardiac and a perfusionist and Dr. Barth and one of our anesthesiologists and a number of other people who I don't know who they are, but I remember other people.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  The record reflects that that was Dr. Seshachar.  Everybody refers to him, I'm learning, as Dr. Abhaya.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Abhaya, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Does that refresh your memory?  Was it Dr. Abhaya who was there?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was going on when you came in?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I think they were doing cardiac compressions.  I'm not entirely -- I think they were doing cardiac compressions, and they were still talking about the airway. I'm not entirely sure.  You know, when I came in, I see that they're doing cardiac compressions, and then I just went on to do what I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: And so I'm not really looking around what else is happening.  And at the time my job was to make sure we could get the chest open and if need be put the patient on ECMO.  And so people are getting things ready.  We're opening the chest. And then basically the baby had, you know, return of circulation and we didn't put the patient on ECMO.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And fair to say in order to open the chest, you would have that same concern with the tracheostomy, if a tracheostomy goes in, you would need to have an endotracheal tube placed?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Not really.  If you're in that scenario, then it's like a different -- a different sense of priorities.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember whether there was a tracheostomy in the field, tracheostomy tube or not?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I don't recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I've had some testimony from Mr. Woodford --
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- that when he arrived you were already there.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You were gowned, and you instructed him don't worry about scrubbing or changing into scrub clothes, just put on a gown.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that consistent with your recollection?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Probably.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that what you likely did yourself?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: If someone is dead, just about, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And who else was with you at the table during your part of this procedure?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Probably a scrub nurse to my right and someone in front of me.  You tell me it's Woodford.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Woodford, yeah.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Then it's probably Woodford.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And where was Dr. Barth when you arrived?  Do you recall?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: He was in the room.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Because I remember having two or three words with him, but I don't know specifically.  I remember sort of like the voice and then what we exchanged.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you remember not necessarily the words but sort of the gist, the essence of what it was that you exchanged at that time as far as information about the patient?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Basically we took the patient to get the trach changed and things, you know, deteriorated and the baby arrested.  And I think the endotracheal tube was in place by then.  That part I'm not entirely clear.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Fair enough.  Fair enough. Did you ever learn or did you get information at that time or sometime later how long she had been in arrest by the time that you arrived?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: A few minutes.  I don't have the specifics.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you opened the chest --
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- did you find anything structurally amiss or disturbed from your prior surgery?  Was everything in place and as you expected it to be?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.  I mean, I'm just reading. But my recollection is that, to your question, is no, I didn't find anything unusual.  Then reading my note seems like the obvious things that you looked at, there was nothing out of the ordinary.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: She was -- when the chest was open, however, there was no cardiac activity at that point, correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Seemingly, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you performed direct massage of the heart at that time?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: That's what is written, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And following that within how long would you say it took for the spontaneous activity of the heart to return?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Oh, very shortly because normally if we open the chest and there is no activity and we don't get it going, we cannulate right away.  And that happens generally in a period of five minutes, and so this has got to be less than five.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Mr. Duncan, the perfusionist that I deposed --
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- said there's always a bypass apparatus primed --
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Ready to go.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- set up and ready to go.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: You got it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that oddly enough the room in which it is is actually right off --
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Adjacent, yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Which is -- Room 1 I understand is not the usual room that you operate in.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: No.  Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But in this case it was right next door if they needed it?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Well, let me just correct that. It's a room where we commonly do cardiac procedures.  But usually we reserve another room for open cardiac surgery.  So if there is an emergency, then we use that room, an emergency that requires open cardiac surgery like an aortic dissection or something like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So then in your note you say the sternum was left open.  Just can you explain for me why you decided to leave the sternum open at that time?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I generally do as a precaution in anyone who has arrested.  I don't know how they're going to behave, and that would expedite, you know, us getting back and do what we need to do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Fair enough.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: So yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then you brought her back for closure the next day, I think.  Let me see if I can get that.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Okay.  Yeah, closure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Looks like -- there we go.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Woodford was there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Woodford was there, and Dr. Seshachar was there again, correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I'm looking at, for the record, that note starts on page 158, Bates No. 158. You stated in there -- you can see my highlighting.  Okay?  I didn't mean for you to see that, but it's okay for you to see that. It says postoperative recovery has been excellent.  You meant that in terms of her cardiac status.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have any knowledge at that time about any other -- any injury she had experienced due to her cardiac arrest?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Objection to the form of the question. You can answer.
speaker: MR. BALAGUER

text: I think that the reason why we left the sternum open is to make sure that her hemodynamics would be sound and they would not be an issue, and that would allow us a period of observation.  So after that has taken place and everything seems fine, then we proceeded with the sternal closure. Now, regarding your question, it's impossible really for anyone to say what kind of morbidity she could have suffered from this particular event considering that she's had multiple events that were more profound than this in the previous hospitalization.  So it would be really impossible to say, okay, here is the causality for this. All we know at this particular time is that circulation is good, there is no evidence of any organ dysfunction, liver function's normal, patient is making urine, and the renal function is normal and there is no other evidence that would make us believe that circulation remains vulnerable.  So we closed the chest.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, in the -- following that closure --
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I'm going to go down to the next day, I think it was, or two days, three days.  Two days later.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: On the 1st of April Dr. Richard Schmidt -- do you know Dr. Schmidt?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: He's one of the ENT specialists, yes, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Dr. Schmidt then brought Lily back to the operating room.  This is his note. I don't expect you to be familiar with it, but I'll represent to you that they did a direct laryngoscopy --
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- bronchoscopy --
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- and were able to exchange the endotracheal tube for a tracheostomy tube. Is that your understanding?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Based on the document, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know why it was Dr. Schmidt and not Dr. Barth who brought the patient back?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: I have no idea.  Maybe he was on call, meaning the services structure their work differently, some people in the OR some people do consults, et cetera.  I have no idea.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So fair to say that you did not specifically request him to do this part of the procedure?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Oh, no.  No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then you continued.  She did, from my understanding from the hemodynamic standpoint, then, she did well after this. Is that correct?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Yes, that's my recollection.

text: Sliding.

text: So this is a sliding reconstruction.

text: Yes.

speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: Sliding?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- what the sliding consists of.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: The sliding consists in the fact that you basically transect the trachea --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: -- and open, you know, one end anteriorly and the other end posteriorly, and then you slide one on top of the other. So you effectively shorten the trachea, but you widen it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: The advantage of that is that it doesn't use any foreign material.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: It has the possibility and potential for growth.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And it doesn't interrupt the vasculature?
speaker: MR. ZAKEOSIAN

text: And it doesn't -- well, any surgery in the trachea doesn't, I mean, must not interrupt the vasculature, otherwise you've got a brig problem on your hands.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You could have necrosis, correct. Okay. And did that procedure go well as far as your recollection is concerned?
